Iran’s nuclear program has been a focal point of global attention for decades. In 2022 a [report](https://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/Current_Iranian_Breakout_Estimates_June_1_2022_Final.pdf) by the Institute for Science and International Security claimed that Iran's breakout time - the amount of time needed to produce enough weapons grade material for a nuclear weapon - was basically zero, a claim that was reiterated by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken [in July 2024](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/07/19/politics/blinken-nuclear-weapon-breakout-time/index.html).

However, estimates of breakout time do not account for the technological capability and time required to build a deliverable nuclear warhead ([which has been estimated by some at 1-2 years](https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/research-briefings/cbp-9870/)). In its [2024 Annual Threat Assessment](https://www.odni.gov/files/ODNI/documents/assessments/ATA-2024-Unclassified-Report.pdf), the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence concluded that while Iran does not appear to be currently pursuing development of a nuclear device, the nuclear activities undertaken since 2020 "better position it to produce a nuclear device, if it chooses to do so".

2. The Iranian government states that it has tested a nuclear weapon at any time, and [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) deem the statement to be credible.
3. At least one of these three sources, which will be considered per se authoritative for purposes of this question, reports that Iran possesses or has tested a nuclear weapon: the [Arms Control Association](https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/nuclear-weapons-who-has-what-glance), the [Stockholm International Peace Research Institute](https://www.sipri.org/) and the [Federation of American Scientists](https://fas.org/initiative/status-world-nuclear-forces/).

A "nuclear weapon" is defined as a device designed for military use that uses nuclear reactions to cause an explosion. Mere possession of weapons-grade uranium or development of related technology will not satisfy the resolution criteria.

**The Fiction of a Clear Countdown to the Iranian Bomb**
The notion that Iran is 'five years' away from a nuclear bomb has been a repeated phrase in Western geopolitics for over three decades. However, despite numerous predictions, the country has yet to cross the nuclear threshold. The real issue is not what we know about Iran's nuclear program, but rather the vast amount of uncertainty surrounding it. This uncertainty has led to dangerous decisions, including Israel's war against Iran, which was sparked by Netanyahu's claim that the regime is 'on the verge of completing a nuclear bomb.' The US initially denied direct involvement in the attack, but has since provided political and military support. A message from former President Donald Trump, 'IRAN CANNOT HAVE A NUCLEAR ARMS!', has been used as a blank check for Israel. Despite 30 years of unfulfilled predictions, the 'imminent nuclear bomb' in Iran is not a new concept, but rather a political construct that has been gestating for decades, with Netanyahu as its primary architect. The CIA's 2007 National Intelligence Estimate concluded with 'high confidence' that Iran had halted its nuclear militarization program, the Plan Amad. The verification of this pause came in 2015 with the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), an agreement that limited Iran's uranium enrichment to 3.67% in exchange for the lifting of sanctions. The US withdrawal from the JCPOA in 2018, driven by the same rhetoric of an 'imminent bomb,' triggered Iran's response, which has accelerated the current crisis. Despite this, there is no evidence beyond the expansion of enrichment plants that Iran has the necessary technology or is developing nuclear arms. The difference between enrichment and nuclear arms is a crucial distinction. Enriching uranium is the visible part of the process, increasing the concentration of the fissile isotope 235 from 0.7% natural to 90% (the armament grade). Iran has accumulated a large amount of uranium enriched to 60% since the US withdrawal from the JCPOA. However, having the fuel is not the same as having the 'weaponization,' a set of incredibly complex steps to convert the fissile material into a functional warhead. Iran's resiliency in the face of sanctions, sabotage, assassinations, and cyberattacks has made its nuclear program stronger and more autonomous. The country designs and produces its own advanced centrifuges and has developed the largest and most diverse ballistic missile program in the Middle East. This institutionalized knowledge in the regime has led Israel to eliminate key figures in the nuclear program and launch missile sites. The cycle of violence and rhetoric has accelerated the conviction in Tehran that a nuclear bomb is the only guarantee of survival. Iran's case is a hybrid of the survival logic of North Korea and the strategic ambitions of Pakistan. It shares the logic of survival with North Korea, but also has the strategic ambitions of Pakistan. This dual nature makes diplomacy complex and the 'red line' difficult to decipher. The narrative of a clear countdown to the Iranian bomb is a dangerous fiction. It fixes our attention on a single measurable metric, uranium enrichment, but it is unclear whether Iran has the necessary technology to develop nuclear arms. What seems to have accelerated things is that, now, if the Iranian regime survives, an Israeli attack can only push it towards a more determined nuclear program.
